Question 70) But it was above all the wool that buyers, coming from Flanders or Italy, sought everywhere. To satisfy them, the races were improved by the progressive increase of their dimensions. This growth continued throughout the thirteenth century, and the Abbey of the Cister's Order, where the most rational cattle breeding methods were used, certainly played a determining role in this improvement.
DUBY, G. Rural economy and country life in the medieval West. The text points to the relationship between improvement of pastoral activity and technical advancement in feudal western Europe, which resulted from (a)
A) Growth of slave labor.
B) Development of urban life.
C) standardization of local taxes.
D) uniformity of the production process.
E) deconcentration of the land structure.
